metadata.title: China Details Sept. 3 Military Parade With Joint Formations and New Strategic, Hypersonic Weapons

left: Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council announced a ban on current and certain former government officials from traveling to China for a military parade on September 3, marking the 80th anniversary of the end of the Second Sino-Japanese War.

The ban includes officials responsible for national defense, foreign affairs, and military officers ranked major general or above to prevent Beijing's united front efforts targeting Taiwan, according to Liang Wen-chieh.
Violating the travel ban may lead to penalties like fines or suspension of pensions under the Cross-Strait Act, Liang stated while urging the public not to participate in the parade.
China's Xinhua News Agency reported that President Xi Jinping will review the troops and address a gathering during the parade.
center: Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council announced a ban on current and certain former government officials from traveling to China for a military parade on September 3, marking the 80th anniversary of the end of the Second Sino-Japanese War.

The ban includes officials responsible for national defense, foreign affairs, and military officers ranked major general or above to prevent Beijing's united front efforts targeting Taiwan, according to Liang Wen-chieh.
Violating the travel ban may lead to penalties like fines or suspension of pensions under the Cross-Strait Act, Liang stated while urging the public not to participate in the parade.
China's Xinhua News Agency reported that President Xi Jinping will review the troops and address a gathering during the parade.
right: China will hold a military parade in September to mark 80 years since the end of World War II, featuring new military hardware.
Hundreds of aircraft along with ground equipment will be displayed for the first time, according to military officials.
President Xi Jinping will oversee the 70-minute parade in Beijing, attended by foreign leaders including Vladimir Putin.
Beijing authorities have increased security measures, including checkpoints and traffic diversions, ahead of the parade rehearsals.
